caption: The Michel Ney Monument is located just south of the Garden of the Grand Explorers and Luxembourg Gardens. It is the work of Francois Rude (1853) and depicts the Military commander and Marshal Michel Ney of the French Revolutionary Wars and Napoleonic Wars in military officer attire, holding his sword above his head in triumphant posture. It is an intriguing statue worth a moment of two if planning to visit the Gardens.
Michel Ney, 1st Prince de la Moskowa, 1st Duke of Elchingen was a French military commander and Marshal of the Empire who fought in the French Revolutionary Wars and the Napoleonic Wars.
Beautiful monument of Michel Ney (1769 - 1815), french soldier and military commander during the French Revolutionary Wars and the Napoleonic Wars.
Love Hemingway's description and back story on Mike in A Moveable Feast

Michel Ney, Duke of Elchingen, Prince of Moskowa (Sarrelouis, 10 January 1769 ‚Äì Paris, 7 December 1815), was a French general, Marshal of the Empire under Napoleon Bonaparte. An energetic fighter, endowed with a great offensive spirit and indomitable character, after distinguishing himself during the French revolutionary wars, he took part in most of the Napoleonic wars, distinguishing himself in the Ulm campaign, at the Battle of Friedland, in the Spanish war and above all in the of Russia; during these campaigns he always demonstrated combativeness, personal courage and tactical ability. With a difficult and irritable character, Ney, after having passed to the Bourbons after the first abdication of the emperor, returned to Napoleon's side in the Hundred Days and fought in the Battle of Waterloo. Considered a traitor after the Second Restoration, he was tried and shot. For his contribution to Napoleon's victories, he had received the honorary titles of "Duke of Elchingen" and "Prince of Moskva".

The statue of Marshal Ney is always a sight to behold.  The movie Napoleon was aired recently, and it seems like he's one of the people that's getting a lot of attention, but from what I see, there are a lot of people walking around the statue, and there's only the occasional person taking pictures.

The history of the Luxembourg Palace was strongly marked by the trial of Marshal Michel Ney, Duke of Elchingen, Prince of Moskowa, accused of high treason after his rallying to the Emperor Napoleon who landed from the island of Elba, in March 1815, when he declared to King Louis XVIII that he would bring the usurper back ‚Äúin an iron cage‚Äù. Marshal Ney was judged there expeditiously and lived out his last days there, before his execution, in the early morning, on December 7, 1815, avenue de l'Observatoire. This statue is located near the site of his execution!! For the record: I was born on December 7... but the comparisons stop there...
